text: finally got my carrot back
damn it
hi everyone anthony fantano here
internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review
kindness
world you need a change of mind
kindness is the
musical project of singer-songwriter
multi-instrumentalist producer adam
bainbridge he hails from england and
this album has actually been co-produced
with philippe zadar who has also been
behind the scenes with other indie pop
favorites from cut copy and phoenix and
there's no reason
right now not to believe that kindness
could not sort of get that same sort of
stature this project has had some
attention on it ever since it released a
debut single in 2009 a cover of the song
swinging party by the replacements now
if you put this record on
you're going to run into a hodgepodge of
sounds from the 70s and the 80s that we
used to make fun of in the 90s and 2000s
or the arts but now it's a new decade
we're past 2010 we're getting deeper
into 2012 and the resurgence of genres
like new wave and disco
synth pop funk and r b are far underway
so far underway i would say kindness is
actually kind of late to the party
because this album is coming after after
chill wave one of the largest collective
embraces of of retro recycling in a long
time as well as artists embracing that
disco and and danceable post punk ideal
like hercules love affair or lcd sound
system and the latest lps from toro imoi
and ariel pink have repurposed old
school
for some pretty eccentric pop
songwriting now admittedly i i was
getting a bit tired
of of all this recycling but i think
kindness is
the new face that this party needs to to
kind of keep things going there are
tracks on here that have really brisk
disco drum beats and and bass lines
inspired by artists like sugar hill gang
and there are other moments that feel
like
take that
contemporary r b from artists like
prince or janet jackson plus the
songwriting and the vocal delivery on
this thing can have a very
sort of
naive and vulnerable quality to them and
for me there's no reason to believe that
bainbridge isn't conscious of the
corniness he's dealing in which is why i
think he puts so much effort into trying
to make some of these tracks some of
them sound sort of
unconventional progressive really
working with with some linear song
structures the opener on this thing
morphs almost psychedelically for six
minutes from one idea to the next an icy
synthscape with a with a drum machine
beat at the intro with some pretty fiery
guitar solos over it to a really
beautiful horn interlude with piano
there are some lyrical breaks in the
middle of that saying let the music
become a part of you or
when we dance we're all the same and
being bridges sort of
deadpan vocal delivery makes the the
tune feel a little bit cultish i am a
little on the fence with
his vocal delivery there are moments on
here like the opener where it feels a
little
flat just doesn't really have a strong
personality a strong anything really but
then there are spots on here like that
replacements cover right after the
opener where it comes off heavenly sweet
and then on the second cover song on
this lp you take on anita dobson's lost
pop gem anyone can fall in love the
vocals also feel kind of off they feel a
little bit lazy and in this instance
it's it's almost kind of a good thing
because like in the way anyone can fall
in love the vocals sort of give this
impression that anyone can really sing
this song
plus the song is just wrapped in these
and these really beautifully arranged
flourishes of of horns and and since
sort of adding these nice subtle little
harmonies against the chords as the song
progresses
the next two tracks on here boggle my
mind a bit though the track g up is is
definitely the most uneventful track on
the album some smooth
ambient synthesizer chords matched up
with some very slowly played funk guitar
chords and it's an okay track i wish a
little bit more happened but right after
that song is the most eventful song on
the album g up really fast really upbeat
lots of guitar leads strong
funky disco bass line a really upbeat
drum beat but then the track sort of
fades out abruptly just before
two minutes just as things are getting
kind of heated thankfully it's not too
long until i get to my favorite track on
here that's all right the song opens up
with this beautiful gorgeous
awe-inspiring horn in synth combo the
synthesizer sounds so slick and rich and
the saxophone just has the perfect
amount of splash on it to just make it
bounce
and then when the beat hits and the
synthesizer comes in that squealing
synthesizer it's just magic it's intense
it's heavy it's epic there's this vocal
sample this guy kind of comes in the
beat is bird
strong composition
hard groove
fat husky synthetically manipulated
baseline it just sounds so large and in
charge i'd love to hear more of that
from kindness in the future taking this
very kind of simple meat and potato
genres we're really building them up
into this epic ambitious thing kindness
plays this style off really well even if
he is at times kind of going through the
motions
following the blueprint like on track
such as cyan or even the last song on
here he still manages to present
something that's really enjoyable tight
grooves catchy hooks it's kind of a
mixed bag of style and and quality still
i'm kind of feeling a decent strong 7 on
this thing if you have heard this album
what do you think of it did you love it
did you hate it
